docs.lead_paragraph: IF the 25-below-zero temperature, howling wind and grim effects of altitude sickness do not make most of those trying to scale Mount Everest feel a world away from home, the near-complete lack of communications on and around Everest surely does. This year, just in time for the 50th anniversary of Sir Edmund Hillary's first ascent of Everest, climbers on the mountain will have the chance to connect with the world below by e-mail. That is because Tsering Gyaltsen, the grandson of the only surviving Sherpa to have accompanied Hillary on that famed climb, is planning to build the world's highest Internet cafe at base camp.
docs.abstract: Sherpa Tsering Gyaltsen plans to build world's highest Internet cafe at base camp of Mount Everest in time for 50th anniversary of Sir Edmund Hillary's famous ascent; positioning wireless radios on moving glaciers and insulating gear against cold pose significant challenges; installation will benefit residents of Namche Bazar, who will also get Internet access; photos; maps (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Speaking at a Queens elementary school where students start lining up for lunch before 10 a.m. because of overcrowding, Senator Hillary Rodham Clinton called yesterday for more federal aid to fix aging schools and build new ones. ''We have to focus on the other three R's -- rebuilding, repairing and reinforcing,'' she said at a news conference at Public School 69 in Jackson Heights.

docs.lead_paragraph: Using a relatively obscure fund-raising technique, Senate Democrats raised more unlimited, unregulated soft money than the Republicans did in the 2000 election cycle. The fund-raising success marks a turnaround for the Democrats and puts them into an awkward position as the Senate prepares to take up campaign finance legislation next week. Democrats have long supported an overhaul that would ban soft money, but now some are leery of tinkering with success.
docs.abstract: Senate Democrats raised more unlimited, unregulated soft money than Republicans did in 2000 election cycle; Democrats used new fund-raising technique, called joint fund-raising committee, to attract soft money, donations to support party and its goals rather than candidate; such committees enable candidates to raise soft money indirectly; 14 Democratic Senate candidates who used joint committees raised more than $15 million in soft money, vastly exceeding $2.6 million raised by seven Republican Senate candidates who used committees; Hillary Rodham Clinton used joint committee to raise as much as $9.6 million in soft money; figures are in new report by Common Cause, campaign finance watchdog group; figures put Democrats into awkward position as Senate prepares to take up campaign finance legislation; Democrats have long supported overhaul that would ban soft money; now some are leery of tinkering with success; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hardly anyone noticed last March when American Women Presidents was formed. The goal of the small group, which has headquarters in Sacramento, was lofty enough -- to promote the election of a woman to the White House -- but in the hubbub of the nominating season, the announcement of its arrival on the political scene was almost totally lost. Then came that day in August when the group offered Monica Lewinsky, someone who had already made it to the White House, a job as corporate vice president.
docs.abstract: American Women Presidents, whose goal is to promote election of woman to White House, sends letters to 100 women governors, lawmakers and business leaders, including Sen Hillary Rodham Clinton, urging them to run for president in 2004 (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hillary Rodham Clinton asserted today that personal privacy was being threatened by businesses and medical institutions that routinely collect financial and medical records, and she urged Congress to give consumers control over how such information is used. And in a speech on privacy to broadcast executives, Mrs. Clinton, the Democratic candidate for United States Senate, scolded some New York City television stations for broadcasting videotapes of groups of men sexually assaulting women in Central Park nine days ago without obscuring the women's faces. Some television stations, as well as most newspapers that reproduced still photographs from the videos, obscured the faces of the victims, as is customary in most sexual crime cases.

docs.lead_paragraph: Many a candidate in New York has tripped over the hazardous emotional terrain of Israel and the Middle East peace process. Hillary Rodham Clinton faces a special problem in addressing the subject because of her confusing roles as first lady, administration defender and undeclared Senate candidate. The difficulty cropped up in a different area over the summer when she first endorsed and then opposed President Clinton's pardon of several Puerto Rican nationalists. Last week it emerged again with her handling of the subject of Israel's treatment of the Palestinians, an issue that drew fire from her presumed opponent, Mayor Rudolph Giuliani. The electorate will have plenty of opportunities to weigh such political exchanges. For now, Mrs. Clinton needs to move quickly to clarify her views on Israel to voters who seem perplexed about where she stands. The furor over Mrs. Clinton's trip was sparked by her visit to the West Bank city of Ramallah, where Suha Arafat, the wife of Yasir Arafat, used a joint appearance with her to attack past Israeli policies toward the Palestinians, including what she alleged was the use of toxic gas on civilians. Mrs. Clinton's advisers said the simultaneous translation at the meeting had not made it clear that Mrs. Arafat was doing anything more than making a routine comment about past grievances. A more adroit diplomat, however, might have been alert to the highly charged atmosphere and weighed in with something distancing herself from the comment. Mrs. Clinton did not do so until that night, after the controversy was in full boil.
docs.abstract: Editorial says Hillary Rodham Clinton, who may be running for US Senate seat from New York, needs to move quickly to clarify her views on Middle East peace process to voters who seem perplexed on where she stands; says she faces special problem addressing subject because of confusing role as first lady, administration defender and undeclared Senate candidate (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: After 28 years of sectarian violence in Northern Ireland, peace is quietly settling across this British province. The violence -- between Roman Catholic republicans who want an end to British rule and Protestant unionists who want Northern Ireland to remain part of Britain -- stopped three months ago, when the Irish Republican Army renewed a cease-fire. More than 3,200 people have been killed in the conflict in Northern Ireland since 1969, but none have died since the cease-fire.
docs.abstract: Peace appears to take hold in Northern Ireland three months after IRA renewed its ceasefire, clearing way for Sinn Fein to enter formal talks and stirring Irish hopes for end to long violence; Belfast residents are rediscovering shops, restaurants and public places; photo; streets are considered safe enough for Oct 31 visit by Hillary Rodham Clinton (S)

headline.main: Irish Take Heart as Peace Takes Hold
